div2.p: a)nti\ pollw=n a)\n . . . e(le/sqai, “you would give a large sum.” a)nti\ is here “in return for,” not “instead of.” Avoid any translation which would imply that the money and the clear knowledge were two alternatives, either of which the Athenians might receive. The condition in direct speech would run—e(/loisqe a)/n, ei) ge/noito, but ei)—skopei=te is practically an object-clause to e(le/sqai.
peri\ w(=n. For peri\ tou/twn a(/.
o(/te, like most conjunctions of time, can take a causal sense. But (unlike e)pei/) it is rarely so used.
e)qe/lein = boulome/nwn. The people should be as “willing” to listen as the speakers are “anxious” to be heard.
sumbouleu/ein, sc. u(mi=n.
ei)/ ti k.t.l. Note the careful antithesis of words in ei)/ ti—tis and polla\—e)pelqei=n a)/n.

a)kou/santes should be taken as helping out the sense of la/boite, not as conditional. The protasis to a)\n la/boite and e)pelqei=n a)\n is ei) e)qe/loite a)kou/ein understood from the preceding clause. Nor is the meaning of a)kou/ein quite the same in the two cases: if the Athenians will listen, they may chance to hear something to their advantage.
th=s u(mete/ras tu/xhs. The orator, in claiming attention for his impromptu speech, pays a compliment to the ready wit of his countrymen.
tu/xhs, sc. ei)=nai.
e)pelqei=n a)/n would in direct speech be e)pe/lqoi a)/n, parallel to a)\n la/boite.
a(pa/ntwn, neuter.
mo/non ou)xi/, L. and S. mo/nos, B. II. 5.
e)kei/nwn, “over yonder” in Olynthus.
au)toi=s, emphatic.
au)tw=n, i.e. tw=n pragma/twn.
ou)k oi)=d' o(/ntina, euphemistic. Demosthenes keeps direct reproach till later.
ta/ g' e)moi\=ta/ e)/moige, for euphony.
h)/dh, “at once.”
th\n taxi/sthn. L. and S. taxu/s, C. II. 3.

o(/pws . . . bohqh/shte. Most editors now read bohqh/sete with one worthless MS. In favour of the future it may be argued that the more vivid construction, which is also the commonest, is here called for, and that the weak aorist subjunctive is avoided where it resembles the future in form, while the blending of future and subjunctive after o(/pws may be easily paralleled. But there are several well-authenticated instances of the sigmatic aorist after o(/pws in Demosthenes (cf. below, ii. § 2, iii. § 2), which have been recklessly altered.
pro/teron. For historical instances see § 9 (note).
h(/tis . . . e)rei=. The future is regularly used to show purpose.
de/os, predicative.
panou=rgos, “unscrupulous.”
a(/nqrwpos. Compare the disparaging use of homo in Latin.
deino/s. L. and S. deino/s, III.
pra/gmasin xrh=sqai, “in making the most of what happens.”
tu/xh|, probably impersonal.
a)cio/pistos. Philip the a)/pistos (ii. § 5) may be trusted only when he threatens.
tre/yhtai. The middle is nowhere found in the required sense of “converting to his own advantage.” Any restoration is mere guesswork; perhaps katastre/yhtai is the best suggestion.
tw=n o(/lwn pragma/twn, “of our main interests” (Heslop).
ou) mh\n a)lla/, “however,” literally “not but what.”
e)pieikw=s with be/ltiston (fai/netai). “It may be urged reasonably enough that what is . . . is actually of the greatest advantage to you.”
e(/n' o)/nta, “alone.” e(/na is due to pa/ntwn, its opposite. Cf. the use of plei=sta ei)=s.

kai\ r(htw=n ka)porrh/twn. Very little more than “secret plans.” The words kai\ r(hrw=n kai\ merely serve to lead up to a)porrh/twn, and throw it out into stronger relief. Cf. Virg. Aen. ix. 595, digna atque indigna relatu (=indigna). Hor. Ep. i. 7. 72, dicenda tacenda locutus (=tacenda). Editors, less probably, “his having everything in his sole power to publish or keep secret.”
au)to/n, emphatic.
taxu/. taxe/ws is more usual in prose, taxu/ in tragedy; ta/xa had dropped out of Attic except in ta/x' a)/n.
po/llw| proe/xei, literally (his being all-powerful, &c.) “is far superior.” Turn: “in being . . . he has a great advantage over us.”
a)nastase/ws. Understand u(pe/r, which=peri/ here as with me/rous, though in a different sense. “To save themselves from utter destruction.”
*)amfipolitw=n . . . *pudnai/wn. The Scholiast says that in each case he lost no time in putting to death those who helped him by their treachery; but we have no trustworthy evidence.
o(/lws, “generally speaking.”
politei/ais, “free communities,” a term applied to any form of government administered by poli=tai, and so excluding turanni/s only: but it is often specially used of democracies.
o(/moron (o(mou= and o(/ros).
ta)/lla k.t.l. The order is e)nqumoume/nous pa/nta ta)/lla a(\ prosh/kei (e)nqumei=sqai).
e)qelh=sai. Note the tense, “rouse your spirit.” So parocunqh=nai.
prose/xein, sc. to\n nou=n.
ei)/per pote/, kai\ nu=n=nu=n, ei)/per pote/.
ei)sfe/rontas. It must be remembered that the ei)sfora/ was not a regular tax, but a highly unpopular war tax to which recourse was rarely had.
lo/gos, “reason.”

e)kpolemw=sai, polemou=n tina=“to make a man hostile,” here hostile to Philip, i.e. to rouse them to fight against him. The old reading e)kpolemh=sai, here and in iii. 7, is impossible, polemei=n being an intrans. verb (“to be at war”), which cannot govern an external acc. Perhaps the confusion arises, in the case of these verbs and of kuklei=n, kuklou=n, from the fact that the present participles of both verbs have the same form.
kai\ tau=q), “and that too.”
me/xri tou, “up to a certain point only.”
tau=t), i.e. to\ polemei=n.

e)k tw=n pro\s au(tou\s e)gklhma/twn, “as the outcome of personal grievances.” pro\s is more commonly used, with an acc., of the person against whom the grievance is felt: but as strained relations imply two parties, it may be used with reference to the aggrieved as well. The verb e)gkalei=n is mostly used of legal accusations, the noun e)/gklhma mostly of general complaints or grounds of complaint.

u(pe\r w(=n fob. kai\ peponq., “by reason of their present fears and their past experiences.” Philip had in 351 made an attack on Olynthus, and was now (349) threatening the whole Olynthian confederacy.
paqei=n tau)to\n, “commit the same mistake” (Heslop).
h(/komen, “had returned,” a frequent sense of the word.

*eu)boeu=sin . . . *)amfipolitw=n. In 358 Athens wrested Euboea from the Thebans, who had held it since the battle of Leuctra (371): it was in 358 or 357 that Philip besieged Amphipolis, and foiled the embassy here mentioned by positively declaring that he would hand the city over to Athens when taken.
parh=san e)pi\. For the frequent use of prepositions denoting motion with verbs denoting rest, see L. and S. e)pi\, C. 2, ei)s, I. 2.

ei)/xet' a)/n, not “you would have gained” (e)/sxet' a)/n), but “you would have been in possession of.” So pareixo/meqa is of showing continuous zeal, though “had shown” is all that we can say in English.
pragma/twn, “trouble.”
*pu/dna k.t.l. To Pydna (357) the Athenians seem to have sent no help at all; to Potidaea (356), Methone (353), and Pagasae (352) they sent too late.
kaq' e(/kasta. Object of le/gwn, as though it were e(/kasta alone: not uncommon.
tw=| prw/tw|, “the first that came.”
au)toi/, emphatic. Demosthenes constantly insists that a citizen army must be sent out, not a mercenary force.

r(a/|oni kai\ polu\ tapeinote/rw|, “more complaisant and far more humble.” The conjunction of the words makes this, the natural rendering, necessary. Dr. Sandys renders “easier to attack and weaker.” But r(a/|oni can hardly be defended by the parallel
adduced (Hom. Il. 18. 258), and tapeino/s in the sense of “weak” is not used of persons, but of insignificant states compared with a greater power.
nu=n de/, “but as it is.”
paro\n . . . a)ei/, to be taken together.
h(mei=s, “it is we who have . . . .”
katesths. thlik. k.t.l. “have raised him to a higher pinnacle than any king of Macedon has ever reached.”
ou)deno\s e)la/sswn, “better than any.” Cf. ou)x h(/kista, “above all,” for the Greek love of mei/wsis or understatement.
a)/n is almost always divorced from its proper verb by oi)=mai and dokw=. Here it is repeated with e)/xein.
logisth/s. Editors point out that the idea of calculation is followed up in qei/h, a)nti/rropon, and § 11.
katasta\s . . . a)\n e)/xein, in direct speech would be ei) katastai/h, e)/xoi a)/n.
u(phrgme/nwn. L. and S. u(pa/rxw, A. 4.
a)melei/as . . . qei/h. Cf. § 1, th=s u(mete/ras tu/xhs u(polamba/nw.
eu)erge/thma does not affect the construction of eu)noi/as. It is added to emphasise this as a special instance of general eu)/noia.
The subject to paro/moion is something like to\ th=s eu)noi/as, i.e. the question of (gratitude for) benefits (in politics).
o(/per. The antecedent is tou/tw| understood.

a)
 me
 ga k.t.l., i.e. a)
 sw/sh| tis o(/s' a)
 la/bh|.
sunanh/lwse, momentary aorist.
to\ memnh=sqai th\n xa/rin. A genitive would be more usual, but cf. Phil. ii. § 30, tou\s a)dikou=ntas memnh=sqai. The reading has been suspected without due reason.
tw=n pragma/twn, “politics.”
ou)d' ei). Regularly put for kai\ ei) . . . ou).
pro\s, “in accordance with.”
e)kba/n, “result.” a)pobai/nein is commoner in this sense.
tw=n pri\n u(parca/ntwn are the opportunities which they have squandered all along, and for which they feel no gratitude.
prohso/meqa. Here of abandoning men to their fate: supra, § 9, of throwing away opportunities.
ei)=ta=ka)=|ta, as often. Notice how the absence of connecting particles throughout §§ 12 and 13 adds vigour to the story of Philip's onward course.
to\ kwlu=on . . . e)/stai. More emphatic and rhetorical than kwlu/sei.
badi/zein. The word for an advance by land) (plei=n, supra, § 8. We might have had mh\ badi/zein.
*pu/dnan k.t.l. Cf. supra, § 9 (note).

*fera/s. In 352 Philip, after being twice defeated, gained a complete victory over Lycophron, despot of Pherae (who was helped by the Phocians under Onomarchus), and took first that town, then its port, Pagasae.
*magnhsi/an. Whether the district or a town bearing the same name, is uncertain.
pa/nq) sums up the names.
ei)s *qra/|khn. Still in 352, as we see from iii. § 4. In the interval the Athenians had roused themselves sufficiently to stop his march into Greece at Thermopylæ.
r(a/|sas . . . r(a|qumei=n. A pun. “When somewhat recovered he did not relapse into remissness.”
*)olunqi/ois e)pexei/rhsen. Cf. supra, § 7 (note).
*)illuriou\s kai\ *pai/onas. In 351, after a partial conquest, 359-8.
*)aru/bban, King of the Molossians.

a)/n tis ei)/poi. The authority for a)\n beginning a clause is very slender, but all MSS. give it in § 19, and none here have ei)/poi tis
a)/n. In the one passage of Plato where it is found, ti/ ou)=n; precedes, as here and in § 19.
w(s, “how,” not “that.”
a)lusitele/s. Cf. supra, § 9, note on ou)deno\s e)la/sswn.
h(=| xrh=tai kai\ suzh=|, “which never leaves him,” “which is his constant attribute and companion.”
u(f' h(=s . . . sxh/sei, “which never will suffer him to rest.”
pra/ttein, “to aim at.”

e)lpi/s, sc. e)sti/, “we may expect.” Expectation of any kind, not hope only, is the original meaning of the word, cf. the neutral e)/lpomai. The future or aorist (sometimes present) infinitive may equally be used after verbs of hoping or expecting.
o(/stis a)gnoei=, “that he really does not see,” admitting the possibility more than would w(/ste a)gnoei=n.
ei) tou=to genh/setai, “if this does happen.” The “monitory” form of future protasis.
e)pi\ toi=s mega/lois to/kois. e)pi/ of the conditions, after daneizo/menoi. So e)pi\ pollw=|, below. The article is unsatisfactory.
tw=n a)rxai/wn, “their original property.”
a)pe/sthsan, gnomic aorist.
zhtou=ntes, sc. poiei=n.
w(=n=tou/twn a(/, partitive gen. after polla/: but the insertion of kai\ xalepa\ is awkward.
ei)s a)na/gkhn e)/lqwmen. With infin., for a)nagkasqw=men.
to\ me\n . . . panto\s ei)=nai, to\ d' . . . sumbou/lou, “that whereas any one can . . . a counseller should give his opinion.” For the genitives, cf. sapientis est, &c.
a)pofai/nesqai, sc. gnwmh/n.
e)n o)rgh=| poiei=sqe. L. and S. poie/w, A. V.
ou) mh\n is strongly adversative to me\n.
skopou=nta, sc. e)me/, supplied from the succeeding h(gou=mai: or perhaps tina/.
u(postei/lasqai. See L. and S. for this favourite metaphor.
dh/, “well now,” proceeding to business.
toi=s pra/gmasin, “the situation,” “the position.”
e(te/rois, i.e. a second force, different from the reinforcements to be sent to Olynthus.
o)knw= mh/. A rare construction. The verb is mostly used of hesitation or shyness. When used of fear, it implies moral fear.
poiou/ntwn . . . bohqhsa/ntwn. The participles contain the most important part of the condition, the sense being ei) . . . poih/sete kai\ parasth/setai, and ei) bohqh/sete kai\ proskaqedei=tai.
parasth/setai. L. and S. pari/sthmi, C. II. 1.
a)munei=tai, sc. th=| oi)kei/a|.
prosk. kai\ prosedr. toi=s prag., “vigorously blockade and besiege the position” (Dr. Sandys).
oudeni/. Vague and strange for ou)de/si (v.l.), or ou)demi/a| po/lei.

[stratiwtika/], if retained, spoils the whole section, in which Demosthenes is walking with great caution over thin ice, in referring to the uses of the Theoric Fund (for which see note on iii. § 11). With studied vagueness he says, “Money you have, but you take (i.e. spend) it according to your own tastes.” With stratiwtika/ retained, these last words become a direct reproof, after which ti/ ou)=n;—e)/gwge is absurd. And Demosthenes would scarcely be so fatuous as to say, “Far be it from me to propose that the military fund should be a military fund.”
a)/n tis ei)/poi. Cf. supra, § 14 (note).

tau=t' ei)=nai stratiwtika/. These words do not clash with ma\ *di/) ou)k e)/gwge, because h(gou=mai is strongly opposed to gra/feis. In effect: “I think it the right course, I admit, but you will insist on spending the money your own way: then why should I make a useless proposal?”

mi/an su/ntacin k.t.l., literally “that there should be one and the same regulation for taking money and doing one's duty,” i.e. that only those who perform military service should get money from the state.
ou(/tw pws, “just anyhow.” See L. and S. ou(/tws, IV.
e(orta/s. The first definite reference to to\ qewriko/n.

dh/ marks a real proposal. But it is only made in order to force the people to the course which Demosthenes dare not himself propose. He passes on hastily from the hated ei)sfora/ to the general conclusion dei= de\ xrhma/twn.
dei= . . . deo/ntwn. Play on words.
eu)trepw=s, “ship-shape.”
w(s a)\n ka/llista, sc. e)/xoi.
au)to/n. Sometimes wrongly taken as standing for po/lemon.

w(s e)piw/n. Explained as=e)c e)pidromh=s, “at the first onset.” This is probably right, but, as Dr. Sandys points out, this use of w(s is elsewhere confined to adverbs and adverbial phrases (w(s a)lhqw=s, w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/, &c.).
a(/panta . . . a)nairh/sesqai, “carry everything with him,” the metaphor in Greek being the same.
ta\ tw=n *qettalw=n, “the attitude of the Thessalians”: taken up by tau=ta, where ou(=toi would be more natural.
komidh=|, sc. a)/pista, “uncommonly treacherous.” The origin of this colloquial adverb is as uncertain as that of the very similar oppido in Latin.
w(/sper h)=n merely repeats the me\n clause.
dw/soien. The future optative is only used after historic tenses of verbs of saying, thinking, or planning, to represent a fut. indic. in direct speech: but very commonly the indic. is kept.
karpou=sqai, explanatory infinitive.
de/oi. By a very rare use the construction of w(s is continued where we should expect dei=n.
ta\ koina\ . . . dioikei=n, “to provide for state expenses.”
toi=s ce/nois. Dative after a substantive. Cf. Latin obtemperatio legibus, &c.
a)lla\ mh/n, literally “but verily,” introduces a new point, like kai\ mh/n. ge strengthens the asseveration, not to\n *pai/ona.
a)\n ei)=nai for a)\n ei)=en of direct speech.
tino/s, “a master.” Not “any master.”
a(/nqrwpos. Cf. supra, § 3 (note).
ou)de/n, adverbial.
to\ ga\r eu)= k.t.l. Philip is u(bristh/s, because, according to the old Greek proverb, ti/ktei ko/ros u(/brin. Translate “Undeserved success puts the senseless on the road to folly.”
a)formh/, literally a starting-point.
th\n a)kairi/an . . kairo\n . . nom., “regarding his time of need as your time for action.”
e)f' a(\ dei=, “for the necessary purposes.”
pro\s th=| xw/ra|, sc. th=| h(mete/ra|.

pw=s oi)/esqe does not affect the construction of logiz. a)\n e)lqei=n au)to/n, being merely a colloquial way of turning e(toi/mws into a superlative. Cf. Av. Ach. 24 w)stiou=ntai pw=s dokei=s; / e)lqo/ntes a)llh/loisi peri\ prw/tou cu/lou.

ei) mhd) . . . ou) tolmh/sete. ai)sxu/nomai, like qanma/zw, a)ganaktw=, &c., may be followed by ei) ou) or ei) mh/. Euphony and habit produce ei) mh\ here (as in ii. § 25), and we expect a positive verb to follow, ei) mhd' a(\ being for ei) kai\ a(\ . . . mh\ (tolmh/sete). But when that part of mhde/ which means “even” has done its duty, Demosthenes disregards the mh/, and gives a more vivid picture with ou) tolmh/sete.
pa/qoite = poih=sai, “to treat him as he would treat you.”
th\n u(pa/rxousan implies only length of tenure: th\n oi)kei/an appeals to sentiment. Attica, of course, is referred to.
*qhbai=oi, like a)lla\ *fwkei=s and a)ll' w(= ta=n, is the answer of an imaginary objector. The Thebans were united with Philip against the Phocians in the Sacred War.

mh\ li/an pikro\n h)=, “perhaps it may be too hard a saying, but . . .” This is said to be the only instance in the orators of mh/ introducing an independent cautious assertion. Plato is very fond of this construction, in which the idea of actual fear is never present, nor is a verb of fearing understood before mh/. “We have here the original deprecatory force of ‘mh/, let it not.’ In a writer like Plato this mh/ has become simply a suggestion put politely, and with a delicate irony” (Thompson, Attic Syntax).
tw=n a)topwta/twn, neuter.

a)\n ei)/h, ei) mh\ pra/cei. The fut. indic. is allowed, because optat. with a)\n is here only a softened form of the future; and pra/cei is more telling, as it almost prophesies action on the part of Philip.
e)klalei=, “blurts out,” not “blabs.”
h(li/k' e)sti\n ta\ dia/fora=o(/son diafe/rei. The infin. following is very rare.
au)tou/s, either referring to personal service, or (more probably) to the absence of an enemy.
e)/cw, sc. th=s po/lews, in Attica.
a)na/gkh, sc. e)sti\ lamba/nein.
le/gw, “I mean,” introducing the conditional clause mhdeno\s o)/ntos.
h( u(/bris, i.e. the outrages inflicted by the enemy. Unlike u(bristh/s, supra, § 23.
tw=n pragma/twn, “such a state of affairs.”
ou)demia=s e)la/ttwn. Cf. supra, § 9 (note).
a)pwqei=n does not imply that the war is now in Attica, but that it must be thrust into Macedonia before it comes (h(/cei above).
w(=n, attraction of relative.
kalw=s poiou=ntes. Here a formula of content rather than of thanks. “Which they happily possess” (Heslop).
e<*>n h(liki/a|, sc. strateu/esqai.
foberoi/. A strong word, suggesting a terrifying aspect. Translate “dread” or “grim,” not “formidable” or “redoubtable.”
a)kerai/ou (a). kera/nnumi) is proleptic, as the position of the article shows. “To keep it inviolate” (Heslop).

tw=n pepoliteume/nwn au)toi=s. The dative of the agent is rarely used except as neuter plural after perfect passives (usually the participle). The dative after pra/ttw is far the most common instance (cf. below, tw=n pepragme/nwn au)toi=s).
eu)/qunai, metaphorical.
pra/gmata, “circumstances”; pepragme/nwn, “conduct.”
xrhsta\ d' ei)/h. The more important speeches of Demosthenes usually end with words of good omen, sometimes couched, as here, in the form of a prayer.
e)pi\ pollw=n. L. and S. e)pi\, A. III. 3.
gignome/nhn. Notice the tense. “To see . . . being openly vouchsafed.”
th=| po/lei depends both on eu)/noian and fan. gign.

to\ ga\r k.t.l. The long sentence introduced by to\ gegenh=sqai and extending to a)na/stasin is the subject of e)/oiken. Turn: “for it seems really a . . . blessing that men have come forward to fight . . . who are.”
tou\s polemh/sontas=tina\s oi(\ polemh/sousi. Here the future denotes willingness rather than purpose.
o(/moron, sc. *fili/ppw|.
tina/, “considerable.”
patri/dos . . . a)na/stasin, “their country's deathblow.” More forcible than patoi/da a)nasthsou/sas.
au)tou/s, emphatic: self-help is needed, as well as divine help
o(/pws mh\ . . . do/cwmen. Cf. i. § 2 (note).
xei/rous . . . tw=n u(parx. “Less kind to ourselves (Heslop) than circumstances have been to us,” literally than what we have already.
tw=n ai)sxrw=n, neuter. Cf. i. § 26, tw=n a)topwta/twn menta)\n ei)/h.
po/lewn. Inversely attracted from acc. by the succeeding relative w(=n.

e)/xein filotimi/an, “does honour to his enterprise.” filotimi/a is properly an emulous seeking after distinction, but here the second factor in the word is used twice, as though it were timh\n u(pe\r filotimi/as. It is never merely “honour,” as taken by editors here and elsewhere, but honour for showing public spirit or the like.

ou)xi\ kalw=s pepra=xqai. Some such word as ai)sxu/nhn was expected to finish the sentence after h(mi=n d), but Demosthenes changes it to a vaguer phrase which does not follow e)/xein at all, but dokei=. “While to us—it is a record of failure.”
u(pe\r th\n a)ci/an, “beyond what he deserves.” Cf. i. § 23.
kexrh=sqe toi=s pra/gmasi. Cf. i. § 3.
ai)sxu/nhn w)flh/kate. Defines ou)xi\ kalw=s pepra=xqai above.
skopoi=to. Rarer than ske/yaito.
e)nqe/nde, not merely “from Athens” but “from this spot,” i.e. the assembly or platform, as shown by toi=s . . . pepoliteume/nois.
w(=n follows both xa/rin and di/khn, thanks for, vengeance for.
toi=s . . . pepoliteume/nois, middle.
le/gein, sc. tau=ta, from w(=n.
a(\ de/. The relative is carried on with the next two clauses.
e)/ni, sc. le/gein.
a)khkoe/nai. The tense is important.
boulome/nois, conditional.
dokima/zein, sc. au)ta/. Always used of a close scrutiny: technically of examining a magistrate before he was admitted to office, or a youth before he was classed among men.
e)le/gxein, sc. au)to\n e)pi/orkon ka)/piston o)/nta.
tou= t' . . . kai\ tou\s. . . Some MSS., but not the best, give tou= again after kai/. Its omission is certainly curious, but not unparalleled.
u(perekpeplhgme/nous. For the acc., cf. Soph. El. 1045, kai\ mh\n poih/sw g' , ou)de\n e)kplagei=sa/ se.

diecelh/luqen . . . “has run through all the arts of deception by which he rose to greatness” (Heslop). Others, with little probability (though the Greek will bear the rendering), take diec. intransitive, with pa/nta as subject.
parakrouo/menos. The metaphor is obscure: see L. and S. for two explanations of Byzantine lexicographers: neither is convincing.
me/gas, proleptic.
ta\ pra/gmat' au)tou=, “his career” (Heslop).
sfo/dra, with the adjectives.

th\n . . . eu)h/qeian . . . prosagago/menon, “that he won over our simple hearts by declaring . . .” The participle agrees with to\n *fi/lippon understood from above. eu)h/qeian, which is thrown prominently forward, is separated from its governing verb first by a temporal sentence and then by the instrumental tw=| . . . fa/skein . . . kai\ . . . (tw=|) kataskeua/sai.
*)olunqi/ous, i.e. Hierax and Stratocles in 358-7. See i. § 8.
a)ph/launon, imperfect of attempt, though not necessarily unsuccessful. So Heslop, “set themselves to . . .”
e)nqe/nde, as supra, § 4 (note).
qrulou/menon, imperfect participle, helped out by pote/.
a)po/rrhton. The secret agreement was that Philip should hand over Amphipolis to Athens, and receive Pydna in exchange.
kataskeua/sai. For the omission of tw=| cf. supra, § 5 (note on tou=). The word is used of “trumping up” a fraudulent pretext.
fili/an and *qettalou\s are governed by prosag. carried on.

kai\ tou\s me\n . . . Where any antithesis may be made, the Greeks prefer co-ordinate sentences with me\n and de\, where we should say “and by wronging his former allies (the Potidæans) in handing them over to the Olynthians.” Here the antithesis between verbs and datives is merely verbal, but it is accentuated by chiasmus.
*magnhsi/an paradw/sein. No such promise is recorded elsewhere.
a)ei\ with e(ka/stwn, “of each in turn.” A common use of a)ei\, especially with participles. Cf. infra, § 30 (note).
proslamba/nwn, literally “taking to himself,” i.e. “turning to his own use.”
ou(/tws takes up e)capatw=n and proslamba/nwn. Omit in translation.
dia\ tou/twn and dia\ tw=n au)tw=n tou/twn are neuters. It was by means of cheating that Philip raised himself; he will be dragged down now that (e)peidh\) he has been proved a cheat.
o)fei/lei, not “he ought to,” but “he owes to,” i.e. in retribution will be dragged down.
kairou= . . . pro\s tou=to=pro\s tou=ton to\n kairo/n.
pro\s . . . pa/resti. Cf. i. § 8 (note).
h)\. The first h)\ is “or else” (cf. Latin aut), the others “or.”
pisteu/sousi, sc. au)tw=|.

para\ th
 au(tw=n a)ci/an, “unworthily” rather than “undeservedly.” Either rendering might do for para\ th
 a)ci/an, i. § 23, and u(pe th
 a)ci/an, ii. § 3; but here the added genitive takes the words out of the region of a mere phrase, and calls attention to the inherent “worth” of the Thessalians as Greeks.

kaqe/cein . . . ta\ pra/gmata, “will control events.” I can see no reason, and find no warrant, for the rendering “will maintain his power” (Dr. Sandys, Heslop). Even in poetry kate/xein never has this sense.
o(/tan . . . susth=|. Cf. i. 12 (note).
u(p' eu)noi/as . . . susth=|. As the passive of sune/xein, susth=nai is followed by a preposition of the agent. So a)poqanei=n (passive of a)poktei/nein), &c.
fe/rein. sumfe/rein, which might have been expected after sumponei=n, is only poetical in the sense required, and would also have involved a pun.
pro/fasis, “cause.” Usually=“plea” or “pretext.”
a)nexai/tisen. Gnomic aorist. In using this strong metaphor Demosthenes recalls to the memory of his audience two passages from Euripides (Hipp. 1232, Bacch. 1072) well known to them.
kai\ die/lusen. Either an added metaphor opposed to susth=|, or, more probably, the metaphor is a “buried” one—the more common verb (“destroys”) balancing and toning down the bold a)nexai/tisen.
ei)s with a(/pac only, forming one word.
h)/nqhs' e)pi\ tai=s e)lpi/sin, “puts forth the blossoms of hope,” literally blossoms on hopes. The whole metaphor has a parallel in Shakespeare, Henry VIII., Act iii. Sc. 2:—
“This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth The tender leaves of hope, to-morrow blossoms, And bears his blushing honours thick upon him: The third day comes a frost, a killing frost.”
a)\n tu/xh|. Cf. i. § 3 (note).
fwra=tai curiously disturbs the metaphor. Metaphor and application are joined as in a)nex. k. dielus. above, but in inverse order.

peri\ au(ta\ katarrei=. Like fading flowers round the stem of the
plant (Heslop), katarrei=n being the regular word for the falling of leaves or petals.

a)rxa\s . . . u(poqe/seis. The words are carefully chosen with a view to the simile, each being used both of material “foundations” and of moral or intellectual “principles.” Cf. ii. 2, th\n a)rxh\n o)rqw=s u(poqe/sqai.
ou)k e)/ni, “is not to be found.”
dh/. Cf. i. § 17 (note).
o(/pws for w(s, with the superlatives.
le/gei, “proposes.”
tau=ta, i.e. our preparations.
*pagasa\s a)paitei=n. Cf. i. § 22. The perfect tense used in both cases shows that the claim was a recent one, and that the two speeches were delivered about the same time.
lo/gous poiei=sqai, “to remonstrate” (Heslop).
deiknu/ein (more commonly deiknu/nai), to “point to,” not, of course, to “display.”
o)/ntwn e)pi\ toi=s pra/gmasin, “devoting yourselves to action.”
a(\n a)ph=|. A general supposition in present time: the apodosis of such conditions is always in present (or gnomic aorist) indicative.
ta\ pra/gmata. A better antithesis would be ta\ e)/rga (given by one good MS.).
e(toimo/tata. We should expect the comparative.
au)tw=|, i.e. speechifying, in which the Athenians were proficient beyond all others.
dokou=men, “are reputed.”
meta/stasin, “reformation,” metabolh\n, “change,” the former denoting a more fundamental and lasting alteration.
ei)/per . . . prose/cei, “if you expect any one to attend to you.” For ei) me/llei prose/xein, but shows more impatience.
e)qelh/shte. Cf. i. § 6 (note).
kai\ dh/=h)/dh. With an infinitive it is curious and very graphic. v.l. kai\ dei=.
ta\ summaxika/. Practically equal to oi( su/mmaxoi.
e)n prosqh/kh|, “as a complement.” For the use of e)n cf. e)n pare/rgw|, “as a secondary consideration.” Cf. iii. § 31 (note).
meri/s, literally share, i.e. “addition.”
oi(=on u(ph=rce . . . “For example, it was of assistance to you.” The verb should be taken as absolute, parallel to e)fa/nh ti and e)boh/qhsen. Others understand meri\s ou) mikra/.

e)pi\ *timoqe/ou. In 364 B.C. the Athenian commander Timotheus led a force against the Olynthian league, and with the help of Perdiceas III., elder brother and predecessor of Philip, took Torone and Potidaea.
e)fa/nh ti, “proved considerable.”
tou=to, i.e. the Macedonians.
sunamfo/teron. Two constructions are blended:—
1. *)olunqi/ois . . . tou=to prosgeno/menon.
2. tou=to (of Macedonians and Olynthians combined) sunamfo/teron.
nuni/, “lately,” rarely used of past time without dh/.
e)pi\ th\n turannikh\n oi)ki/an. See i. § 13, note on *fera/s.

ka)
. The a)
 in this word has no regular construction, though no doubt the preceding a)
 facilitates its use. From the fact that kai\ a)
 often began a conditional sentence, ka)
 ei) came to be used for kai\ ei), and then ka)
 alone for kai\ “even.” Cf. Soph. El. 1482, a)lla/ moi pa/res / ka)
 smikro
 ei)pei=n.
pa/nt' w)felei=, “it is altogether of service,” pa/nta being acc. plur. adverbial.
kakw=n, “weak points.”
tou/tois, instrumental, oi(=s, causal dative.
tou=t' e)zh/lwken, “has made this his passion” (Sandys). tou=to= to\ do/chs e)piqumei=n.
proh/|rhtai. Always of deliberately choosing a definite course: whereas just below the simple ai(rei<*>sqai, followed by a)nti/, is of preferring one course to another.
pra/ttwn k.t.l., i.e. pra/ttein te kai\ kinduneu/ein kai\ paqei=n . . . “To run a career of action and peril, and therein to suffer . . .”
a)\n sumbh=| ti=o(/ ti a)\n sumbh=|, object of paqei=n.
th\n . . . do/can, a long stretch.
filotimi/as, “glory.” Cf. ii. § 3 (note).
kopto/menoi, “shattered.” A very strong word.
tai=s a)/nw ka/tw, “hither and thither.” a)/nw ka/tw is more common in the sense of “upside down.”
toi=s e)/rgois, “agriculture.” A special use of the word which was never quite lost in Greek. Cf. the title of Hesiod's agricultural poem, *)/erga kai\ *(hme/rai.
poih/swsin, “produce”—the earliest meaning of the verb, the sense “to do” being a later extension. Cf. poihth/s.
ou(/tws o(/pws a)\n dun., “as best they can,” i.e. under these difficulties.
diaqe/sqai, “to dispose of” by sale, literally to arrange for their advantage.
*fili/ppw|. For the more usual pro\s *fi/lippon.
oi( de\ dh/. The dh/ is probably ironical.
ou)d. oi(/ou te yeud. So we say of a man that “he couldn't tell a lie if he wanted to.”
ou)de/nwn . . . belti/ous. Cf. i. § 9 (note).

oi(=os e)/mpeiros. The verb e)sti\n may be easily understood after oi(=os, and of course this is grammatically the origin of such an expression. But, as part of a phrase, oi)=os is depreciatory and almost adverbial, “to any extent skilled.” E.g. in Av. Vesp. 970, o( d' e(/teros oi(=o/s e)stin oi)kouro\s mo/non, where the position of e)stin makes anything but a colloquial explanation of oi(=os impossible.
filotimi/a|, “through personal ambition.”
e)/fh. The subject is to be supplied from the tino/s of § 17, fin.
toi=s a)/llois, i.e. his other failings.

th
 filot. a)nup. The adjective may quite naturally be taken as agreeing with th
 fil. (tou= *fili/ppou). Others take it with to
 *fi/lippon understood, th
 fil. being acc. of respect.
a)/llws. Such an idiomatic use of a)/llos is scarcely to be translated. It means properly “to take another virtue, besides swfrosu/nh.”
loipou/s, predicate.

oi(/ous . . . o)rxei=sqai, “the sort of people to . . .” Contrast supra, § 17, oi(/ou te yeu/desqai. The ultimate reason for the distinction made in sense by the addition of te is obscure. Demosthenes probably alludes to kordakismou\s above.
o)knw= has here its proper meaning. See i. § 17 (note).
qaumatopoiw=n, “mountebanks.”
to\n dhmo/sion. This term is so general for a public slave, or servant, that we can only guess at the occupation of Callias. He may have been a clerk like Æschines.
mi/mous, verbal, not substantival. So poihta/s (cf. supra, § 16, note on poih/swsi).
ei(/neka tou= gelasqh=nai, literally for the sake of their (tou\s suno/ntas) being laughed at, i.e. “to raise a laugh at their expense.”

tou/tous a)gapa=|. Rarely used as a transitive verb of “feeling affection for,” except in the Homeric a)gapa/zw. Plato and the classical writers generally use it in the sense of being content, with dative, conjunction, or participle.

kakodaimoni/as. An evil dai/mwn or genius might bring a man (1) utter wretchedness, or (2) madness, infatuation, as here. The literal meaning is more constant in this word than in its opposite eu)daimoni/a. The words gn. kai\ kak. are not a hendiadys; kai\ does not couple, but explains, as often, the vaguer by the more definite word, literally “the state of his mind, I mean his infatuation.”
tou/tois, i.e. toi=s dei/gmasi.
to\ katorqou=n. Used as an intrans. verb by prose writers only: as trans. it is, like a)norqou=n, a favourite of the tragedians.
ptai/sei, sc. o( *fi/lippos.
au)tou= depends on tau=t).

dei/cein. Understand au)to\ (often expressed) as subject, literally “that the event will show” (i.e. “what it will show,” not “what I say”). Besides dei/cei and au)to\ dei/cei, we have au)to\ dhlw/sei (Dem.) and au)to\ shmanei= (Eur.).
qe/lwsi . . . bou/lhsqe. Cf. i. § 1 (note).

e(/ws, MSS. te/ws. On such a point the authority of MSS. is almost valueless. In the time of Demosthenes te/ws had its own duties as demonstrative, and it is hard to believe that it could be relative as well. Later, it ousted e)/ws as relative, and copyists persistently wrote the form familiar to their own age.
ou)de\n e)paisqa/netai, “does not notice that anything is wrong,” the sense of ou)de\n being made clear in the following clause.
kinei=tai, “is disturbed.”

ka)
 r(h=gma, ka)
 stre/mma, sc. h)=|, not saqro
 h)=|.
tw=n u(parxo/ntwn, “of the system.”
po/lemos sumplakh=|. More forcible than polemw=| sumplakw=sin, as showing that the war has the grip of them and they are likely to be thrown.
e)poi/hsen. For the tense, cf. supra, § 9, a)nexai/tisen.
tau/th|, “in this respect.”
me\n introduces a polite concession to this view; ou) mh\n a)lla\ opposes it.
mega/lh . . . r(oph/, literally “is a great preponderance,” i.e. “makes a great difference.” More commonly r(oph\n e)/xein.
ma=llon de\ to\ o(/lon, “or rather, all the difference.” Take to\ o)/lon adverbially, r(oph/ e)sti being equivalent to r(e/pei.
au)tw=n, emphatic.
kata\ mikro/n is found meaning (1) “little by little,” (2) “to a slight extent,” as here.
plei/ous a)forma\s ei)s, “more to depend upon for,” literally startingpoint, then “capital,” which is the metaphor here. Cf. i. § 23.
oi)=mai, “to be sure.”
au)to\n, sc. tina\, “a man himself.”

mh/ ti/ ge, “much less.” Cf. Latin ncdum (sometimes nc). In both cases there is an ellipse of a subjunctive, here e)pita/tth|s. The full construction would be, “I say not even, lest you should think you can order.”
e)f' a(/pasi, “on all occasions.”
mh/te kairo\n mh/q' w(/ran paral. A slight zeugma.
e)kei=no. The object thrown forward, referring to what follows. In English we can only say “this,” not “that”; but cf. Latin illud (commoner than hoc).

ei) *lak. me\n . . . nuni\ de\. . . . A good example of the Greek use of co-ordinate clauses, where we should make the four main verbs in the me/n clauses subordinate. They say, “I wonder that you did indeed resist,” &c. (as we know that you did), “but that now . . .” where surprise is not expressed at the resistance, but at the subsequent slackness in face of previous resistance. In English, “That, whereas you resisted,” &c. “you now. . . .”

*laked . . . a)nth/rate. This refers to the war taken up in 378 B.C. by Athens and Thebes. The independent rights of Greek cities, which had been secured in 387, had been constantly violated by Sparta, notably when she seized the Acropolis of Thebes in 383.
dikai/wn, “rights.”
tu/xwsi, more graphic than tu/xoien.
proekinduneu/ete, sc. tw=n a)/llwn.
kaq) e(/n) au)tw=n. kaq) e(/na forms a substantive here=e(/kaston. So kaq' e(/kasta, i. § 9 (note).
po/son polemei=te xro/non. So pa/lai, polu\n xro/non, and Latin iamdudum, iampridem take present, not past.
ti/ poiou/ntwn, i.e. ti/ e)poiei=te e)n w(=| o( xro/nos. . . So mello/ntwn and the other participles below. Cf. i. § 18 (note).
au)tw=n = e(te/rous tina/s.
krino/ntwn, sc. tou\s strathgou/s.
pa/lin e)lpizo/ntwn. In connection with krin. as the Schol. shows. The accused generals would be prodigal of promises.
a)gnwmo/nws e)/xete. a)gnw/mwn is (1) unreasoning, as here; (2) unfeeling.
w(/ste . . . e)lpi/zete. Cf. note on o(/stis a)gnoei=, i. § 15, “that you really expect.”
e)/xon e)sti\ fu/sin=e)/xei fu/sin. fu/sis forms no adjective of the required sense, but e)/xon e)sti\ fu/sin parallels eu)/logon more closely than would e)/xei fu/sin.
e)/xontas fula/ttein, for ful. a(/ a)/n tis e)/xh|.
pa/nta, object of kth/sasqai, and perhaps, but not necessarily, of fula/ttein as well.

ta\ kaq' u(ma=s e)llei/mmata, “your own shortcomings.” And at the same time (says Demosthenes) your new vigour will leave the generals no excuses: you will be able, when your objects are gained, to judge them on their merits, since you are so fond of judging.
pikrw=s, “severely.” Very rare in a good sense.
ei) dei= ti, “if I must state a fact or two about the generals as well” (on whose faults you are always insisting, but who seem to me outside the question).
e)ntau=qa me/n, “whereas in this war” (your war with Philip).

ka)\n lhfqh=|, sc. ta)=qla, for *)amfi/polis is almost certainly a gloss, as this speech is in no way concerned with the recovery of Amphipolis, and the position of kai/ in ka)\n is very awkward. Moreover, lh/mmata below shows clearly that lhfqh=| is used in a general sense of prizes of war. *)amfi/polis was probably inserted by a copyist or commentator who was not equal to giving more than the most literal meaning to lhfqh=|.

u(mei=s, emphatic, opposed to i)/dioi. In the war with Philip the generals and soldiers run all the risks, and you would get all the prizes of success: in their self-sought wars, they run fewer risks and get considerable profit.
misqo\s d' ou)k e)/stin, “and reward they have none,” i.e. to compensate for the risks. It need not mean that they could not get their pay.
do/ntes lo/gon. dido/nai lo/gon is (1) to render an account, (2) to grant a hearing, as here and infra, § 31.
ta\s a)na/gkas, “their hard case.”

peri/esti, “the result is,” literally “it remains over.” The preposition in this verb (as in perigi/gnomai, &c.) has its less usual force (like the Epic peri/ with gen.) of “beyond,” “exceeding.” Thus periei=nai is (1) to surpass, with gen., (2) to remain over, whether as a survival or as a consequence.
u(mi=n. We should expect me/n to follow, to parallel ta\ koina\ d).
e)ri/zein. A poetical (and Platonic) word.

kata\ summori/as. Demosthenes here metaphorically applies the rules for tax-collecting to party politics. When a certain ei)sfora/ was needed in 377 B.C., it was arranged that henceforth it should be collected from four classes, graduated in wealth, with a h(gemw/n (“head”) and an e)pimelhth/s (“superintendent”) attached to each. The highest class numbered the 300 most wealthy citizens, the second more (less wealthy), the third more still, and the fourth most of all. [L. and S. are wrong in speaking of the 1200 most wealthy citizens: this applies only to the extension of summori/ai to the trierarchy, which took place in 357 B.C.—an arrangement with which, though prior to this speech, we are not concerned here.] Applying this system to the state of the two political parties, Demosthenes says that each party has a r(h/twr (corresponding to the h(gemw/n) and a strathgo/s (corr. to the e)pimelhth/s). The r(h/twr defends the strathgo/s (e.g. Chares) in the assembly. And each side has its noisy partisans (corresponding, very inaccurately, it must be confessed, to the 300 wealthiest citizens). Translate: “For in former times you were divided into partnerships for paying the war-tax: now you are divided into partnerships for playing the politician.”
e(kate/rwn refers back to toi=s me\n . . . toi=s de\ . . . above.
w(s. L. and S. C. iii.
tau=t' e)pane/ntas, literally “relaxing this,” i.e. “abandoning this policy.”

u(mw=n au)tw=n . . . genome/nous. gi/gnesqai with gen. is (1) “to become one of,” e.g. Ar. Nub. 107, tou/twn genou= moi, “please join them,” (2) with gen. of reflexive pronoun, “to become one's own master,” as here.
koino/n, “free to all.”

w(/sper e)k turanni/dos u(mw=n, literally “as though from the position of a tyranny over you,” i.e. “as though they exercised lordship over you.” The gen. construction which follows the verb turanneu/ein is here extended to the noun.

toi=s de\ yhf. mo/non. The first class has all the power, the second all the duties, the third has only votes, and these it uses against the generals, trierarchs, &c., of the second class (kata\ tou/twn).
a)ei/, with h)dikhme/non, in the idiomatic sense. “That class which at the particular time has been unjustly treated.” Cf. § 7.
ei)=ta=ka)=|ta. Cf. i. § 12.
e)/cestai, ironical.
le/gw, “I bid you.”
dh/. Cf. i. § 17 (note).
kefa/laion, literally “as a summing-up.”
o( dei=na. In Demosthenes we find:— Sing. Plur. N. o( dei=na. oi( dei=nes. Too close. A. to\n dei=na. — G. tou= dei=nos. tw=n dei/nwn. D. tw=| dei=ni. —
The derivation of the word is very obscure.
ou)xi\ tau)ta\ . . . gignw/skein, “to take a totally different view.” For the mei/wsis, cf. i. § 9 (note).
proh/konta. Represents the same tense as proelh/luqen, § 3.

w(/ste . . . de/on=w(/ste dei=. But as the whole sentence is subordinate to o(rw=, which is followed by a participle, dei= follows suit. Cf. Goodw. M.T. 607 (a). Others, with less probability, understand e)sti/ (de/on e)sti\=dei=).
kakw=s, with peiso/meqa.
ou)de\n a)/llo . . . h)/. Originally some such word as poiei=n would be expressed to govern ou)de\n a)/llo. But it has become almost an adverbial phrase, “merely.”
th\n u(po/qesin, “the subject,” literally “groundwork.” Cf. the derivation of the word “subject.”
ou)xi\ th\n ou)=san=yeudh=.
a(marta/nein. Absolute, with parist. “to be at fault in. . . . ”
ge/gonen . . . tau=t' a)mfo/tera, “both these chances have been offered to us.”
tou=to. Object of prolabei=n, explained by o(/pws—sw/somen.
bebai/ws u(pa/rch|, “has been effectively secured.”
th\n prw/thn. L. and S. pro/teros, B. iii. 1. Cf. infra, § 21, th\n a)/llws.
sw/swmen. Cf. i. § 2 (note).
peri\ tou= ti/na tim. tis, literally “as to the (question) whom one shall punish.” The article makes the direct question ti/na tim. tis; into a substantive. The alliteration is perhaps intentional.
o(\n tro/pon=ti/na tro/pon. The relative is sometimes used for the interrogative, though a distinction may be marked in most cases.

th
 a)rxh
 . . . u(poqe/sqai, “to lay the foundation.” Cf. ii. § 10, ta\s a)rxa\s kai\ tas u(poqe/seis. § 1, th
 u(po/qesin (note).
o)rqw=s, “aright.” Appropriate to the building metaphor. Cf. o)rqou=n (poetical) and a)norqou=n (prose), specially used of the restoration of temples, forts, or houses.
ei)/per pote/. A curious blending of (1) o( parw\n kairo/s, ei)/per tis, dei=tai, (2) nu=n, ei)/per pote, dei=.
a)kou/wn, “by hearsay.”
tw=n pragma/twn, “our interests.”
h)/. Depends on ta\ plei/w. Where the article is used with the comparative (as here), we generally find ma=llon h)/.
dia\ tou=to, “with this motive.” dia/, with accusative, usually means “because of.”
pro\s xa/rin, “to give pleasure.” So we have pro\s h(donh\n le/gein (Thuc. ii. 65).
dhmhgorei=n. Cf. dhmagwgei=n.
ei)s pa=n . . . moxqhri/as, “to the utmost limit of wret<*>hedness.”
mi/kra/=o)li/ga.
me/mnhsqe . . . o(/te. The antecedent to o(/te is omitted (tou=ton to\n xro/non). So, in English, “You remember when.”
a)phgge/lqh . . . poliorkw=n. An extension of the use of the participle after verbs of hearing and knowing (a)kou/w, oi)=da, &c.). Cf. i. § 9.

tri/ton . . . e)/tos touti/. In 352, November to December (maimakthriw/n). The expedition is mentioned in i. § 13. “Two or three years ago.” The accusative is regularly used with ordinal numbers of days, months, and years (inclusive), to show when an event happened. ou(tosi\ (never ou(=tos) is often added.
*(hrai=on tei=xos. The site is uncertain, but it must have been close to the Chersonese.

tou\s me/xri pe/nte kai\ tett. All citizens between the ages of twenty and sixty were liable to foreign service, but those over thirty were not very often called out. The exception in this case (as well as the emphatic au)tou/s) shows that the need was pressing.
tou= e)niautou= tou/tou, i.e. the year ending in mid-July, 351—an interval of seven months since maimakthriw/n.
e(katombaiw\n, k.t.l., sc. e)ph=|san.
mhno\s mog. meta\ ta\ must. Observe alliteration. Cf. supra, § 2.
ta\ musth/ria. These took place during bohdromiw/n. This makes ten months since the time of o(/t' a)phgge/lqh.
kena/s = au)tou\s e)mbai/nein.
h)gge/lqh . . . asqenw=n. Cf. supra, § 4 (note).

teqnew/s. For the strong perfect existing by the side of the weak teqnhkw/s, cf. e(stw/s and e(sthkw/s. In the indicative (as with i(/sthmi) we find the strong form (te/qnamen, teqna=si) only in the plural.

ou)ke/ti. The e)/ti is emphatic. The Athenians, after so many postponements, thought that it was no good to send help now, whereas, says Demosthenes, this was (no credit to them) just the lucky moment.
a)fei=te, “you countermanded.”
to\n a)po/stolon. For the special naval sense, cf. L. and S. ste/llw, II.

h)nw/xlei. One of the few verbs which take a double augment. The others are a)ntibolei=n, a)ntidikei=n, a)mfisbhtei=n, a)mfignoei=n, diaita=n, a)ne/xesqai, a)noi/gein, a)mpe/xesqai, o(ra=n (with diakonei=n doubtful).
swqei/s. This is the emphatic word, with a reference to a)sqenw=n h)\ teqnew\s above. Very freely: “Philip would never have been restored to health to be a thorn in our side now.”
ou)k a)\n a)/llws e)/xoi, literally “would not be in a different state,” i.e. “could not be altered” (however much we might try).

panti\ sqe/nei. sqe/nos is an archaic and poetical word, and Dr. Sandys shows that it only survives (in prose) in the above phrase, “with might and main”: further, that kata\ to\ dunato/n is not the language of Demosthenes, and that the five words are probably a quotation from a treaty ratified between Athens and Olynthus. The expression is found often in inscriptions which record treaties.
tina/. Cf. ii. § 1 (note).

e)qa/rrei tou/tous, i.e. kai\ *fi/lippos e)fobei=to tou/tous. qarrei=n, with acc., is a semi-poetical construction, an extension of that following commoner verbs of emotion, such as ai)sxu/nomai, kataplh/ssomai, &c. The object is usually a thing, not a person: e.g. qa/naton qarrei=n (Plato, Phaedo, 88 B.).
h(mei=s, sc. pro\s e)kei/nous.
w(/sper. L. and S. w(/sper, II.
e)mpo/disma . . . dusxere/s. Note the metaphor from hand and foot.

e)formei=n toi=s e(autou= kairoi=s. The last three words are commonly taken as “opportunities against him.” But e)formei=n can only be used of a fleet watching to strike: hence the dat. following, whether the verb is literal or metaphorical, must refer to the enemy. Translate, as Dr. Sandys, “his critical moments,” “his weak points.”
e)kpolemw=sai. See note on i. § 7. Here the *fili/ppw| is understood.
o(pwsdh/pote. Disparaging; implying that the result was not due to Athens, but ge/gon' au)to/maton (i. § 7, a passage which should be compared with this section).

perista/shs a)/n. a)\n, with a participle, stands for a relative followed by a)\n and the finite mood demanded by the verb in the “if” clause. Curiously, u(fei/meqa could be either aorist indic. or aorist opt., but the sense requires the latter. The full expression would be th=s ai)sxu/nhs h)\ peristai/h a)/n.
kaqufei/meqa. The metaphor is from the slackening of sails, and is common in the simple verb.

e)xo/ntwn . . . a)peir. Conditional participles, as we see from the mhdeno\s with o)/ntos in the corresponding clause. Apart from this necessity, they would be better taken so than as causal, as they form the protasis to mikro
 o(rw=. Thus, mikro
 e)so/menon o(rw=, e)a
 e)/xwsi . . . kai\ a)peirh/kh|.
w(s e)/xousi. Euphemistic for e)xqrw=s.

a)peirhko/twn de\ k.t.l., “and the resources of the Phocians are exhausted.” The primary idea of a)peipei=n in post-Homeric times is “to say . . . not.” Hence it came to mean (1) “to forbid”; (2) “to renounce” (literally to say that you will have nothing to do with); (3) intrans., “to faint,” “fail” (literally to say that you cannot). The connection of (2) and (3) may be seen from the trans. and intrans. uses of “to give up” in English.
ta\ paro/nta. A vague way of referring to the Olynthians.

e)pikli=nai. Intransitive. “Not to ‘incline towards’ (L. and S.), but to ‘turn against,’ ‘press heavily on’” (Sandys). This is probably right, since the verb is used literally of the pressure of one substance against another.
poih/sein. The use of future instead of present serves to make the dilatoriness more marked.
e)/gguqen. Poetical word.
to\ d' o(/pws. Cf. our phrase, “The why and the wherefore.”

nomoqe/tas. A number of jurymen (we do not know how many) were yearly chosen to form a board to deal with changes in the laws. As such an appointment at the regular time could not be para/docon toi=s polloi=s, we must assume either that Demosthenes proposes the establishment of an extra board, or that no election had taken place for the last year at least. The latter view is probable: it seems inconceivable that Demosthenes should not have said “appoint another board” of nomoqe/tai, if one was at this time sitting.
kaqi/sate. A technical term. See L. and S., kaqi/zw, I. 4.
e)n . . . nomoqe/tais, “in their court.”
qh=sqe. For the difference between tiqe/nai and tiqe/sqai no/mon see L. and S., ti/qhmi, A.V.

tw=n qewrikw=n. The people had now come to regard as their right the dole which Pericles had first given them as a favour, and the surplus of yearly expenditure was now regularly paid into the Theoric Fund. It seems probable that Eubulus, at some time between 354 and 350, had passed laws (tou\s ei)s to\ paro\n bla/ptontas u(ma=s) forbidding the alienation of this fund. Hence, in i. § 19, Demosthenes only dares to hint at the nature of his proposal, and even here demands that the authors of the laws shall themselves incur the odium of repealing them. One Apollodorus (probably in 348) was fined by the law courts for actually passing such a proposal through the Senate and Assembly, and it was not till 339 that Demosthenes carried the day.

safw=s ou(twsi/, “to speak quite plainly.” ou(/tws is idiomatically added for emphasis (probably with an accompanying gesture) to certain adverbs, especially safw=s and fanerw=s. Thus, a)/ntikrus ou(twsi/, “just outright;” ou(/tw r(a|di/ws, “quite easily.”
qewrika/. Predicate.

tou\s a)taktou=ntas, “malingerers;” literally “those who will not form
up along with the rest,” i.e. join the army. The rendering “disorderly” (L. and S.) makes no sense; Demosthenes is complaining that certain classes or individuals are exempted from service.
ei)=ta. Causal. “And thus.”
thnikau=ta. Tum demum.

to\n gra/yonta, “some one to propose.” The generalising use of the article with participle. So o( tuxw/n, “any chance-comer;” o( boulo/menos, “any one who wishes.” Cf. ii. 1, tou\s polemh/sontas (note).

a)pole/sqai. This refers no doubt to the loss of civil rights, not to the penalty of death. Any one who might propose the appropriation of the Theoric Fund would be indicted on a grafh\ parano/mwn, or action for proposing illegal measures, as Apollodorus was afterwards: and this offence was punished, not by death, but by a fine. Until this was paid, the person found guilty would be a)/timos, and from a political point of view, a)polwlw/s.
boulh/setai, “shall be anxious to. . . .” Slightly ironical for “shall be prepared to.”
perigi/gnesqai. See L. and S., perigi/gnomai, 3.
paqei=n. For tou= paqei=n, in apposition to tou/tou.
tou\s au)tou/s. Subject of lu/ein.

teqh/kasin. Inscriptions clearly show that forms like te/qeika, e)lelu/kein, ei)rgazo/mhn, &c., are far later than Attic. About the end of the second century B.C. ei) began to supplant h in many words, mainly verbs, and as manuscripts were being largely multiplied at Alexandria at that period, many such barbaric forms have been perpetuated until our own time. Cf. note on e(/ws, ii. 21.

xa/rin. It is not strictly accurate to say that the “popularity” or “odium” affected the city for good or evil; it was affected by the proposals which made their originators popular or unpopular. The expressions are elliptical for xa/rin tou/twn a(\ . . . and a)pe/xqeian tou/twn di) w(=n.
u(pa/rxein . . . gene/sqai. Note the contrasting verbs and tenses. The popularity (won in the past) is spoken of as “continuing”; the odium (referring to the future) as being suddenly “incurred.”

zhmi/an. This predicate comes in awkwardly. The whole sentence should be so turned in translation as to give greater prominence to the persons spoken of: “that those who . . . should continue to enjoy . . . while the man who . . . should incur. . . .”
a)ciou=te, literally “think fit,” i.e. “allow.” From the same literal meaning come the senses “require” or “demand” (supra, § 12, fin.), “ask” (iii. 3), “claim,” and “believe,” all with infinitive.

proqu/mws, separated from poiei=n, that it may have an emphatic position towards the end of the sentence, while the still more emphatic position of u(ma=s makes it clear that the citizens themselves must act.
peri\ w(=n grafei/h, i.e. tau=ta peri\ w(=n, “the objects for which they were passed.” The optative is used because the number of decrees is indefinite.
diapra/casqai, “to accomplish of themselves.” au)ta/ would probably have been added but that the preceding au)ta/rkh is enough. The object is tau=ta understood out of w(=n.
u(bri/kei, sc. a)/n.
ei(/neka/ ge yhfisma/twn, “if resolutions could have done it.” This use of e(/neka for “as far as regards,” without any causal idea, is frequent both in prose and verse.
th=| ta/cei, “in order of time.”

th=| duna/mei, “essential importance” (Sandys). Not in the philosophic sense of “virtually,” “potentially” (as L. and S.). Stripped of its antithetical dress, the plain meaning is: The one important thing is action, not the debate which precedes it.
par' u(mi=n, s.c. ei)si/.
duna/menoi. We should expect oi( dun.
gnw=nai, “to decide on.” The verb never means to “know” except in perfect, e)/gnwka (literally I have ascertained).
kai\ . . . de/. An earlier writer would have written kai\ . . . ge or kai\ dh\ kai/.
pra=cai is emphatic, of action as opposed to speech and thought: poih=te, neutral, of conduct, “if you do what you ought to do.”

ou)x . . . peiso/meqa. ou)x goes with this verb as well as with proei/lhfe, not that it is “understood” in the second case, but because words like ou) and ei) can influence both parts of a me\n . . . de\ sentence, in the same way as a figure or letter in algebra influences everything contained in a bracket immediately following.
tau/ths, i.e. the land of the Olynthians, not Attica.
pa/ntwn. Other passages in Demosthenes make it probable that this word is masculine.
polemh/saien . . . polemou=ntai. See note on i. § 7.
ou)k e)xqro/s; A sudden and impressive change of subject.
e)/xwn. More forcible than e)/xei, as being parallel with the two adjectives.

ba/rbaros. Although the races under Philip's rule at this time were mainly non-Hellenic, both Herodotus and Thucydides assert the Grecian descent of the reigning house. Both Alexander I. (some 130 years before) and Philip himself, in 356, had been allowed to compete, and had been victorious, in the Olympian games. But Macedon had held such slight intercourse with the Greek states that the bitter taunt is perhaps half justified; and the fact that Philip was a tu/rannos (cf. i. § 5) would settle the question with the members of a free Greek state.
ou)x o(/ ti a)\n . . . “Isn't he—anything you like to call him?” i.e. no name can be too bad.
mo/non ou)xi/. Cf. i. § 2.

sugkataskeua/santes, “helping him to add them to his own pro
perty.” kataskeuh/ is a general word for the contents of an estate, including stock, furniture, outbuildings, &c.
to/te=thnikau=ta. Supra, § 11.
dia\ pa/ntas, k.t.l. Emphatic: these are really oi( ai)/tioi th=s fugh=s.
kai\ nu=n, k.t.l. Three suppositions are put forward in the sentences ou) le/gei . . . e(/teros . . . and ou)x h(de/a . . . and after each comes the orator's reply.
a)gaqh=| tu/xh|, “and may it bring good luck.” This was a formula used to preface decrees, and in ordinary life as a pious wish when any new step was being taken.

ou)ke/ti — a)dikei=, “This is not the speaker's fault,” literally “not now,” as it was in the case of ou)—be/ltista. Dr. Sandys sums up well the sense of kai\ nu=n—a)dikei=: “Do not blame your advisers, but follow the best advice, however unpalatable it may prove.”
plh\n ei) . . . “unless he fails to put up a prayer when he ought.” Demosthenes ironically hints that the Athenians think more of formulas than of sound advice.
de/on eu)c. paraleip. Beware the construction.
ei)s tau)to/, like ei)s e(/n, “together.”
e)n o)li/gw|. Probably here of space, not time: “in little compass.”

prote/qh|. Put impersonally for pra/gmata proteqh=|. Note the careful antithesis of words between this sentence and the last: eu)/casqai = e(le/sqai, o(/sa bou/letai = pra/gmata, r(a/|dion = ou)k eu)/poron.
fh/m' e)/gwge, ei)/per e)/stin, “I quite agree, if such a thing is possible.”
qauma/zw ei). . . . More commonly this means, “I wonder that . . .”
eu)porh=sai, “to find means in.”

tw=n a)po/ntwn, “what he has not” (Heslop), tw=n a)p. being opposed to ta\ paro/nta, “what he has,” merely to form a verbal antithesis. “What he has lost” is less probable: a state of poverty, not a change from riches, is implied in tw=n a)po/ntwn.
eu)porh=sai, with gen., is slightly extended from its usual meaning, “to have good store of.”
me/ga u(pa/rxei. Either (1) “is a great support to,” or (2) “counts for much in,” as probably here.
r(a=|ston . . . e)sti/, sc. tini/. Cf. supra, ii. § 23.

o(ra=te . . . o(/pws, k.t.l. All the three verbs that follow depend on o(/pws: “consider how the facts stand, and how you will be able . . .” ou(/tws need not be translated. In the same way, for tau=ta, though the direct object of o(ra=te, we should say, “in regard to this.”
e)nde/xetai. Generally impersonal.
swfro/nwn. sw/frwn never means “wise.”
tw=n tou= pole/mou. Not with xrhma/twn.
e)pi\ me\n . . . *fi/lippon de\. See note on ii. 24.
*korinqi/ous kai\ *megare/as. It has been thought that this refers either—
(1.) To the attack made on the two territories in 458, and on Megara by Pericles in 431.
(2.) To recent invasions of which we know nothing, though in Speech 13 (not written by Demosthenes) there is an incidental mention of an attack on the Megarid.
(3.) To neighbouring Greek states taken at random.
Probably (2) is correct. If Demosthenes had been thinking definitely of events 100 years old, he would have stated the facts more particularly.
*(ellhni/das. It is implied that Philip is ba/rbaros (supra, § 16).
e)fod. toi=s strat. Cf. i. 22, trofh=s toi=s ce/nois (note).
a)kou/w. In perfect sense: commoner than a)kh/koa, where events which happened some time back are referred to.
oi( pario/ntes, sc. e)pi\ to\ bh=ma.
ou) pa/nu. This may either be taken as “not at all,” its commonest meaning, or, more probably, as “not altogether,” ironical.
th=s politei/as, “of statesmanship.”

to\n *)aristei/dhn, k.t.l. See Index of Proper Names. A special instance of public spirit on the part of Aristides may be found in the warning given to his enemy, Themistocles, before Salamis (Her. viii. 79), and on the part of Pericles in his brave defiance of the Athenians, when they clamoured to go out from the city against the Spartans who were ravaging their estates (Thuc. ii. 21-22). Nicias was nothing if not conscientious; the earlier Demosthenes we only know as a vigorous and capable general.
e)kei=non=clarissimum illum.

oi( dierwtw=ntes, “who are always plying you with such questions as . . .” But note that “always” is expressed rather by the tense than by dia/, which rarely expresses continuity of action, but often thoroughness or vigour, as may be seen from a study of the parallel words die/resqai, dieipei=n, dihgei=sqai, dii+sxuri/zesqai, &c.
pefh/nasi=exstiterunt.

prope/potai th=s parauti/ka xa/ritos, “have been recklessly squandered for a momentary gratification.” The history and examples of propi/nw should be carefully studied in L. and S. It is unlikely that here there is any direct reference to “giving away in booncompanionship,” though in Fals. Leg. 296 (t<*>n e<*>lenqeri/an propepwko/tes *fil<*>) Demosthenes uses the more literal meaning with effect, in view of orgies already mentioned. With the present passage cf. <*> (Hector rebuking the <*>
tw=n te . . . kai\ tw=n, i.e. contrasting the one with the other. This disjunctive use of te . . . kai\ is rare.
e)fi/loun, “caressed.” Half-way between the common senses “to love” and “to kiss.”
au)tou/s. Note the change from relative to demonstrative, which always occurs where the first verb is followed by another which would require a different case.
pe/nte kai\ tettara/konta e)/th, i.e. from the formation of the Delian confederacy, 478-6, down to the outbreak of the Peloponnesian war in 431.

e(ko/ntwn. A very partial statement of the case. However willing the allies were to join the league originally, they constantly revolted throughout the period, and were one after another, with the exception of Chios and Lesbos, reduced to the condition of subjects.

plei/w h)\ mu/ria ta/lanta. According to Thuc. ii. 13, the greatest amount of coined silver ever deposited in the Acropolis was 9700 talents, but he also mentions 500 talents of uncoined gold and silver as lying there at the beginning of the Peloponnesian war.
a)nh/gagon, literally “carried up,” i.e. “deposited.”

u(ph/koue. It is absurd to speak of the shifty Perdiccas II. as having been subject to the Athenians. He played fast and loose with Athens from the beginning of the war till his death, and, though entering into agreements with her more than once, did considerably more service to her enemies.
tau/thn, i.e. Macedonia. Cf. supra, § 16 (note).
e)/sthsan tropai=a, metaphorical. “Won triumphs.”
au)toi/. Cf. i. § 9 (note).
mo/noi . . . kate/lipon. Probably a reminiscence of Thuc. ii. 41 (from the funeral speech of Pericles), mo/nh ga\r (h( po/lis) tw=n nu=n a)koh=s krei/sswn e)s pei=ran e)/rxetai.
tw=n fqonou/ntwn. Instead of tou= fqo/nou. Concrete for abstract.
e)pi\ . . . tw=n *(ell., “in regard to.” A rare use, extended from such phrases as e)pi\ pollw=n (ii. 1). With *(ell. understand pragma/twn.

ka/llh . . . i(erw=n. It is only in his most lofty passages that the orator would use such a poetical phrase, and it is for these higher flights that he reserves such sonorous language as that of w(/ste mhdeni\ tw=n e)pigignome/nwn u(perbolh\n lelei=fqai.
tw=| th=s politei/as h)/qei, “the spirit of the constitution.” h)=qos (to be carefully distinguished from e)/qos) is that indefinable attribute of men and things which we call “character.”
h)=san me/nontes. See note on ii. § 26, e)/xon e)sti\ fu/sin.

ei)/ tis a)/r' oi)=den, “if any of you happens to know,” a)/ra implying that there is no special reason why they should. This use of a)/ra is very common after h)\n (e)a\n), “if it turns out that . . .”

o(poi/a pote/=o(poi/a tis, the addition of the enclitic making a slight difference, which cannot be kept up in English here. Thus poi=o/s <*>)sti; means “what kind of man is he?” poi=o/s ti/s e)sti; “what is his essential character?”
ei)s periousi/an, “with a view to amassing a fortune.”
e)pra/tteto au)toi=s. See i. § 28 (note).
to\ koino\n au)/cein. Cf. Hor. Od. ii. 15. 13:
“Privatus illis census erat brevis, Commune magnum.”
e)kei/nois, i.e. toi=s progo/nois.
oi(=s ei)=pon. Attraction of relative, and of the antecedent into relative clause.
prosta/tais. So during the Peloponnesian war the statesman most in favour with the people was called o( prosta/ths tou= dh/mou.
xrhstw=n, ironical. “Worthies” (Heslop).
oi(=s—agrees with h(mi=n above, but is left without construction, as the form of the sentence is changed at e)peilhmme/noi.
a)\n e)/xwn. Cf. supra, § 8 (note).
o(/shs. Cf. note on oi)=s ei)=pon above.
e)rhmi/as. “‘A clear field,’ a metaphor from the public games, kept up in tw=n prwtei/wn and brabeu/ein” (Sandys). In Phil. i. 49, tw=n kwluso/ntwn is added.

e)peilhmme/noi. The nom. participle is followed (in the same concessive sense) first by three genitive absolutes, and then by an accus. absolute, until the first construction is taken up in a)pesterh/meqa.
*laked. . . . a)polwl. At Leuctra in 371.
*qhb. . . . a)sx. o)/ntwn. Since 355 the Thebans had been fully occupied with the Sacred War.
ta\ di/kaia, “the claims.”
xw/ras oi)kei/as. Amphipolis, Pydna, and Potidæa. Cf. i. § 12 (notes).
ou(\s d' e)n tw=| pole/mw| summa/xous. The war is that undertaken in 378 by the Athenians and Bœotians jointly against Sparta. In the same year Athens formed her second maritime league.
ei)rh/nhs ou)/shs. The Social War waged by Athens against her revolted allies lasted 357-355, and during this period Athens was at peace with the other Grecian states.
h)skh/kamen, “trained.” For the metaphor see § 27, note on e)rhmi/as.
h)/. Cf. ii. § 8 (note).
a)ll' w)= ta=n. See i. § 26 (note).
lh/rous, “absurd trifles.” Demosthenes charges Eubulus and the peace party with distracting the minds of the people from external dangers by means of a few paltry improvements in the city.
tw=n politeuome/nwn, masc. middle.
a)gaphto/n. For the verb a)gapa=n see ii. 19 (note).
tw=n a)/llwn e(ka/stw|, i.e. toi=s politeuome/nois.

e)kneneurisme/noi, “have had your sinews ripped out.” The metaphor is strange to English, and we can scarcely do justice to the idea of moral deterioration implied in the loss of “fibre.” It is highly improbable that “sinews of war” are meant, though this view has met with some support owing to the next words (perih|r. xrhm.).
e)n u(phr. . . . gege/nhsqe, “have been reduced to the position of mere servants and appendages.” Cf. ii. 18, e)n ou)deno\s me/rei. ii. 14, e)n prosqh/kh|.

*bohdro/mia pe/mywsin, “celebrate the procession of the Boedromia.” This festival was held on the 6th day of the month *bohdromiw/n (about September 26), in honour of Apollo *bohdro/mios (Helper in battle), and Artemis the Huntress. It commemorated a mythical Athenian victory, but whether that gained by Theseus over the Amazons or by Erectheus over Eumolpus is uncertain. There is a curious reading *boi+/dia given for *bohdro/mia by ancient citers of Demosthenes: it is probably due to a copyist who did not understand the above use of pe/mpein.
to\ pa/ntwn a)ndreio/taton, “bravest thing of all,” in apposition to the next clause. Demosthenes here puts ironically what he had said above seriously in e)kneneurisme/noi.
au)tw=n does not, of course, agree with tw=n u(mete/rwn. Cf. ii. 24.
oi( de/, demonstrative.
kaqei/rcantes. The people are “cooped up” in the city like animals in a cage, to be tamed.
e)pa/gousin e)pi\ tau=ta, “coax you on to these enjoyments.” The same metaphor is kept up to the end of the sentence.
neaniko/n. Sometimes used in a bad sense, derived from the folly (not, as here, from the high spirit) of youth.

o(poi=) a)/tta ga a)
. The indefinite a)
, with subjunctive, can only be separated from its relative or conjunction by little words like me/n, ga/r, &c. o(poi=) a)/tta are regarded as one word, as in i. § 28, o(poi=) a)/tt' a)
 . . . peristh=|.
tau=ta. Accusative after ei)po/nti, which here means “tell of,” not “say.”
tw=n pepoihko/twn=h)\ toi=s pepoihko/sin.
a)lla\ nu=n g' e)/ti, “even now.” a)lla\ nu=n and a)lla\ su\n xro/nw| are common in tragedy.
a)formai=s, predicate.
ta)/cw tw=n a)gaqw=n=ta)/cw a)gaqa/.
te/leion, “consummate.”
lhmma/twn, “petty gains”; generally with an idea of dishonesty.

toi=s a)sqenou=si . . . siti/ois didome/nois. The two datives and the position of the article make this sentence a very clumsy one. If the text is sound, we can only take the words in the following order: a(\ e)/oike toi=s siti/ois didome/nois a)sqenou=si, for though a)sqenou=si seems sorely to need an article, siti/ois must have one. The tone of voice would easily prevent any ambiguity in the actual delivery. Of course it is easy to cut out a)sqenou=si, but this is a policy of despair.

para\ tw=n i)atrw=n . . . didome/nois. Not “given by doctors:” this would introduce a use of para/, which, though found in Herodotus and Plato, would be impossible in the more chastened prose of the orators. Taken in conjunction with Plat.
